div.p: Greetings. You have here, my most esteemed lord and brother, a messenger who will faithfully bring to me anything you were going to write. I have nothing, except that from Italy it is reported that the war is raging fiercely before Parma. Ravenna is said to have suffered some damage; the French are faring well, etc.

The Venetians are said to have discovered a betrayal that the imperial forces had prepared against them, similarly the Genoese also discovered one and are said to be in a bad situation with the emperor. It is also said that the people of Magdeburg have recently achieved a great victory in a sortie. If you have anything, let me know, especially how the matter of the council stands. Farewell. Zurich, 12th of July, 1551.
To the most excellent man, Lord Oswald Myconius, my honorable lord and dearest brother.
